question: The number of daylight hours in New York State changes with what part of the year?

content.source_1: Earth’s axis is tilted about 23.5 degrees, causing the length of daylight at mid‑latitudes to vary with the time of year (longer in summer, shorter in winter).
content.source_2: New York State lies between roughly 40.5° N and 45.0° N latitude, a mid‑latitude range that exhibits pronounced seasonal shifts in day length.
content.source_3: At the equator, the duration of daylight is about 12 hours throughout the year, with very little seasonal variation.
content.source_4: New York City (~74° W) and Quito, Ecuador (~78.5° W) are only a few degrees apart in longitude, placing them near the same meridian.
content.source_5: Locations at nearly the same longitude experience local solar noon at nearly the same moment by the sun’s position, because longitude aligns solar time.
content.source_6: New York State stretches nearly 8 degrees in longitude from its eastern to western edges, creating about a half‑hour difference in local solar time across the state.
